                                            By 
                                                    Issac J. Bailey


                                            By

                                            By 
                                                    Barney Frank


                                            By 
Benjamin Wofford


                Jeb Bush speaks at an event in Nevada. | Getty

            By 
Eliza Collins

11/05/15 06:21 PM EST
Jeb Bush is promoting his new book this week — a 600-plus-page tome about his email exchanges as governor of Florida — as well as a new campaign slogan: “Jeb can fix it.” He's been passing around his email address, jeb@jeb.org, and urging voters to drop him a line.
Bush's critics have had fun with the struggling presidential candidate, passing around memes of Jeb as Bob the Builder and trolling him on Twitter using the hashtag #JebCanFixIt.
Story Continued Below
And at a New Hampshire town hall this week, three separate voters appeared to take his new slogan extremely literally, asking him detailed questions about septic tanks. ("I'm not going to solve your septic problem tonight, I'm afraid," Bush told one woman.)
Bush has taken the ribbing in good humor, as an email exchange released by National Review reporter Katherine Timpf shows.
First, Timpf tweeted at Bush to ask if voting for him would help empower her to clean her room:

Hey my room is a mess can u fix it @JebBush
He replied with his email address:
@KatTimpf email jeb@jeb.org with the details
She then shared her email:
Please confirm when read @JebBush pic.twitter.com/qeY2aMhgN2
Bush tweeted back:
@KatTimpf sent you some guidance
“I will empower you to clean up your own room. It will be liberating! You will feel good about yourself. You will then live a life of purpose and meaning. You will be inspired to help other to help them clean their own rooms. This is the path to lessen our dependency on Mt Washington. You can do it and I fixed. Jeb,” he wrote.
The book is part of a broader campaign by Bush, who reportedly spent 25-30 hours a week on email when he was in office, to showcase his commitment to transparency and draw a contrast with the investigation into Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton’s private email server.
Bush has been giving out his address for years. But he's deluged with emails since he started more proactively telling voters to send him a note:

Jeb says he has gotten some 800 emails over the last 24 hours. Including one from a man asking if he could fix his toilet.
Asked by POLITICO why he started giving out his personal email address, Bush responded in under two hours.
"I’ve been doing this for years. I love hearing from people," he wrote.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Jeb emails National Review reporter about her messy room
